question: For a pure capacitor:

options.a: the current lags the voltage by 90 electrical degrees
options.b: the current leads the voltage by 90 electrical degrees.
options.c: the current lags the voltage by 180 electrical degrees.
options.d: the current leads the voltage by 180 electrical degrees.

question: Three alternating currents are given by $i_1 = 141 \sin(\omega t + \pi/4)$, $i_2 = 30 \sin(\omega t + \pi/2)$ and $i_3 = 20 \sin(\omega t - \pi/6)$ and are fed into a common conductor. Find the resultant current and its r.m.s. value.
Which of the following impedances is inductive?
The voltage and current through a circuit element are $v = 120 \sin(314 t + 45^\circ)$ volts and $i = 12 \sin(314 t - 315^\circ) A$. Find the value of power drawn by the element.
A coil connected to 120 V DC supply draws 12 A and the same coil when connected to 100 V, AC voltage of frequency 50 Hz draws 6 A. Calculate the power factor.
A voltage $e = 250 \sin(100\pi t)$ is applied to a coil having $R = 200 \Omega$ and $L = 638 \text{ mH}$. Find the power taken by the coil.

A non-inductive resistance of $10 \Omega$ is connected in series with an inductive coil across 240 V, 50 Hz AC supply. The current drawn by the series combination is 12 A. The resistance of the coil is $2 \Omega$. Determine the voltage across the coil.

A coil of resistance $6 \Omega$ and impedance $10 \Omega$ is placed in series with a second coil of resistance $9 \Omega$. When a voltage of 250 V, 50 Hz is applied to the circuit, the current flowing through the circuit is 10 A. Find the inductance of the second coil.
A charge of $4 \mu\text{C}$ is moving along a 0.667 T magnetic field at 320 m/s at an angle of 80 degrees with the field. Approximate the force exerted on the particle:

A coil having a resistance of $10 \Omega$ and an inductance of 0.2 H is connected in series with a pure capacitor of $50.7 \mu\text{F}$. The circuit is connected across a 100 V, 50 Hz A.C. supply. Calculate the voltage across the inductor.

A coil having a resistance of $10 \Omega$ and an inductance of 0.2 H is connected in series with a pure capacitor of $50.7 \mu\text{F}$. The circuit is connected across a 100 V, 50 Hz A.C. supply. Calculate the voltage across the capacitor.

A $0.80 \text{ m}^3$ slab of laminated iron core of berry-type transformer is evaluated for hysteresis loop such that the area under the B-H loop is $62 \text{ cm}^2$. The scale indicates $0.7 \text{ AT/m} = 1 \text{ cm}$ and $0.3 \text{ Tesla} = 1 \text{ cm}$ respectively. Determine the hysteresis loss at 60 Hz:
An RL circuit consumes a current of 66.25 amperes when connected to a 100 V, 60 Hz. When connected to a DC source of 50 V, the power consumed is 400 watts. Determine the inductance of the coil:

As of PEC 082-S2016, an electrical design will run the room of a school using ten 10-V lamps in parallel from a 230-V, 50-Hz supply by inserting a choke coil in series with the bank of lamps. If the choke coil has a power factor of 0.2, find its resistance and inductance of each lamp:

A voltage $v(t) = 220 \sin(314 t + 10^\circ)$ is applied to a circuit and a steady current given by $i(t) = 15.6 \sin(314 t - 20^\circ)$ is found to flow through it. Determine the reactive power of the circuit:
The voltage applied to a coil having $R = 200 \Omega, L = 638 \text{ mH}$ is represented by $e = 200 \sin(100 \pi t)$. Find the average value of the power taken by the circuit:
The power factor of a perfect resistor is:

A coil of inductance 80 mH and resistance $120 \Omega$. In parallel with it is a $16 \mu\text{F}$ capacitor in series with a $40 \Omega$ resistor. Determine the total power taken from the supply of 230 V, 50 Hz.

Two coils are connected in parallel across a 200 V, 50 Hz supply. At the supply frequency, their impedances are 6 and $10 \Omega$, respectively, and their resistances are 2 and $3 \Omega$, respectively. Calculate the total current.

Use voltage division to find the voltage V in the circuit. (Circuit diagram: $30 \Omega$ resistor, $j40 \Omega$ inductor, $50 \Omega$ resistor, $80 \Omega$ resistor, $100/30^\circ V$ source, $-j60 \Omega$ capacitor, $j70 \Omega$ inductor)
